intro: Lepidium divaricatum subsp. trifurcum, commonly known as the three-branched peppergrass, is a flowering plant native to parts of North America. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops and weeds. The plant is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, yellow flowers that appear in clusters. Its leaves are alternate and often have a slightly hairy texture. This subspecies is typically found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of habitats, including roadsides and fields.
